description: Understand related addition and subtraction facts within a family

commonMistakes: Not recognizing all four related facts

description: Identify and use relationships between addition and subtraction

coreConcepts: Addition and subtraction are inverse operations
Using known facts to derive new ones

description: Find the unknown addend in addition equations like 5 + __ = 12

coreConcepts: Use subtraction to find missing addend
teachingTips: Think: What do I add to get to...?

description: Solve word problems with unknown addends
Maintain equality on both sides of a balance

coreConcepts: Balance maintained when same added/removed from both sides

description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign as a relation of equivalence
Solve problems with boxes or blanks representing unknown numbers
Use boxes or blanks as placeholders for unknown values (early algebra)
Solve one-step linear equations using inverse operations

coreConcepts: Balance method: same to both sides
commonMistakes: Not doing same to both sides
teachingTips: Think: what operation is done to x?

description: Solve equations of the form x + a = b
Solve equations of the form x - a = b
Solve equations of the form ax = b
Solve equations of the form x/a = b
Solve two-step linear equations like 2x + 3 = 11

coreConcepts: Box the variable term, think outside the box
Outside the box: use opposites to make zero; Inside the box: divide it out
teachingTips: Box the variable term, outside = opposites, inside = divide

description: Solve equations requiring combining like terms and distribution
Solve equations requiring the distributive property
Solve equations with variables on both sides like 3x + 2 = x + 10

coreConcepts: Get all variables to one side
Get constants to the other side
Special cases: no solution, infinite solutions
commonMistakes: Not moving all variables to same side

description: Solve systems of equations using substitution method

coreConcepts: Solve one equation for one variable
teachingTips: Always check in both original equations

description: Solve systems of equations by adding or subtracting equations

coreConcepts: Add or subtract to eliminate one variable

description: Solve systems by graphing and finding intersection points

coreConcepts: Graph both equations on same axes

description: Identify and understand no solution and infinite solution cases
Add whole numbers fluently
Subtract whole numbers fluently
Count forward from any number
Count backward from any number
Count objects to determine quantity
Count equal groups to find total
Count by 2s, 5s, 10s, etc.
Understand multiplication as equal groups
Interpret 3 × 4 as 3 groups of 4 objects
Multiply single-digit numbers fluently
Add equal groups (introduction to multiplication)
Understand fractions as parts of a whole
Understand 1/4 as one part of four equal pieces
Add fractions with like and unlike denominators
Subtract fractions with like and unlike denominators
Multiply fractions by fractions
Divide fractions by fractions using reciprocals
Simplify expressions by combining like terms
Use properties to generate equivalent expressions
Apply the distributive property to expand and factor expressions
Expand expressions using the distributive property
Understand place value in whole numbers
Break numbers into tens and ones
Combine parts to make wholes
Write numbers in expanded form
Regroup ones as tens, tens as hundreds, etc.
Add multi-digit numbers with regrouping
Understand relationship between parts and whole
Understand addition as putting parts together
Add equal groups to find total
Compare numbers using greater than, less than, equal to
Compare multi-digit whole numbers
Use >, <, = to compare numbers
Understand the equal sign as meaning 'the same as'
Put numbers in order from least to greatest
Understand order relationships among numbers
Round numbers to the nearest ten, hundred, etc.
Round numbers to the nearest ten
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio language

coreConcepts: Ratio notation: a:b, a to b, a/b

description: Identify and evaluate exponential functions f(x) = a·b^x

coreConcepts: a is initial value, b is growth/decay factor
Growth if b > 1, decay if 0 < b < 1
commonMistakes: Mixing up growth factor and rate
teachingTips: Compare table of values: linear vs exponential
Real-world: population growth, compound interest, radioactive decay

description: Evaluate limits using algebraic techniques
Find derivatives using limit definition
Plot and identify points using ordered pairs

coreConcepts: Ordered pair (x, y) where x is horizontal, y is vertical
Four quadrants, x and y axes
commonMistakes: Going up/down first instead of left/right
teachingTips: Remember: 'along the hallway, up the stairs'
Connect to real maps, battleship game

description: Calculate and interpret slope as rate of change

coreConcepts: Slope = rise/run = change in y / change in x
Positive slope rises left to right
Negative slope falls left to right
Zero slope is horizontal, undefined slope is vertical
teachingTips: Connect to real rates: speed, cost per item

description: Factor and simplify rational expressions by canceling common factors

coreConcepts: State domain restrictions (values that make denominator zero)
Simplified form has no common factors
teachingTips: Emphasize: can only cancel FACTORS, never terms
Factor completely first, then look for common factors
Always state what values x cannot equal
Check work by multiplying factors back

description: Multiply rational expressions by multiplying numerators and denominators

coreConcepts: Multiply numerators together, multiply denominators together
teachingTips: Factor FIRST, then cancel, then multiply (less work)
Show connection to multiplying numeric fractions

description: Divide rational expressions by multiplying by the reciprocal

coreConcepts: Keep-Change-Flip: keep first, change ÷ to ×, flip second
commonMistakes: Forgetting restrictions from the flipped fraction
teachingTips: Check: division is multiplication by reciprocal

description: Add and subtract rational expressions using common denominators

teachingTips: LCD is LCM of denominator polynomials
Distribute carefully when rewriting with LCD
Combine ONLY numerators, denominator stays same

description: Prove triangles congruent using postulates

coreConcepts: SAS: two sides and included angle
ASA: two angles and included side
teachingTips: Use color coding for corresponding parts

description: Understand similarity, find scale factors, and solve proportions

coreConcepts: Scale factor = ratio of corresponding sides

description: Solve and graph inequalities including compound inequalities

coreConcepts: Flip inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative

description: Identify patterns, find terms, and sum arithmetic sequences
Work with geometric sequences and find sums, including infinite series
Evaluate definite integrals using Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

commonMistakes: F(a) - F(b) instead of F(b) - F(a)

description: Evaluate and compose functions using proper notation
Calculate and interpret the mean of a data set

coreConcepts: Mean = sum of all values ÷ count
Also called average or arithmetic mean
teachingTips: Real data sets from students lives

description: Find the median (middle value) of a data set

coreConcepts: Order values from least to greatest
Even count: average of two middle values
commonMistakes: Picking wrong middle for even count
teachingTips: Cross off from both ends to find middle

description: Identify the mode (most frequent value) of a data set

coreConcepts: Can have no mode, one mode, or multiple modes
commonMistakes: Thinking there must always be one mode
Finding the highest value instead of most frequent
teachingTips: Tally charts or frequency tables help

description: Calculate the range (spread) of a data set

teachingTips: Connect to everyday language ("range of temperatures")

description: Perform and describe translations (slides) on the coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Translation slides a figure without rotation or flipping
Every point moves the same distance and direction
teachingTips: Use graph paper or coordinate plane
Real: sliding objects, video game sprites

description: Perform and describe reflections (flips) over lines

coreConcepts: Reflection flips a figure over a line (line of reflection)
Each point and its image are equidistant from the line
Preserves size and shape, reverses orientation
commonMistakes: Not preserving distance to line of reflection
Confusing which axis is line of reflection
teachingTips: Count squares from line of reflection
Real: mirror images, symmetry in nature

description: Perform and describe rotations (turns) around a point

coreConcepts: Rotation turns a figure around a center point
Specified by center, angle, and direction (clockwise/counterclockwise)
commonMistakes: Not rotating all points same amount
Forgetting which point is the center
teachingTips: Use tracing paper to physically rotate

description: Describe events as likely or unlikely based on experience

coreConcepts: Likely means it will probably happen
Unlikely means it will probably not happen
Use everyday experiences to make predictions
commonMistakes: Not understanding that unlikely things can still happen
Basing predictions on wishes rather than reality
teachingTips: Use everyday examples: Will it rain? Will you eat lunch today?
Sort event cards into likely/unlikely piles
Connect to weather, daily routines, familiar games
Use picture cards showing different scenarios

description: Use probability vocabulary: certain, likely, unlikely, impossible

coreConcepts: Unlikely: not much chance of happening
Use precise words to describe chance
teachingTips: Create probability word wall with examples
Number line: impossible → unlikely → likely → certain
Spinner activities: which color is most/least likely?
Real contexts: weather, birthdays, coin flips

description: Find probability of simple events using outcomes

commonMistakes: Assuming all outcomes are equally likely when they are not
teachingTips: Use concrete materials: spinners, dice, colored cubes
List all possible outcomes before calculating
Experiments: flip coins, draw from bags
Start with equally likely outcomes only

description: Express probability as fractions (favorable/total)

coreConcepts: Numerator = number of ways event can happen
Denominator = total number of possible outcomes
commonMistakes: Putting total in numerator and favorable in denominator
Thinking probability can be greater than 1
teachingTips: Visual: shade favorable outcomes on diagrams
Connect to real fractions: 3/8 of the spinner is red
Practice with spinners, bags of colored objects

description: Collect and organize data in tables and charts

coreConcepts: Organize data so it is easy to read
commonMistakes: Asking questions that cannot be answered with data
teachingTips: Start with class surveys: favorite color, pet, lunch
Use concrete objects before abstract recording

description: Use tally marks to collect and display data

coreConcepts: One tally mark for each item counted
Cross through four marks for fifth
Easy to count and compare quickly
teachingTips: Count by fives, then add remaining
Use for live data: vehicles passing, birds at feeder

description: Create and interpret frequency tables

coreConcepts: Frequency = how many times each value occurs
teachingTips: Convert tally charts to frequency tables
Ask: Which has most? Least? How many total?
Real data from class or school
Bridge to bar graphs and pictographs

description: Identify and name common 2D and 3D shapes

coreConcepts: Recognize shapes in different orientations and sizes
commonMistakes: Thinking a tilted square is not a square
Not recognizing shapes in different sizes
teachingTips: Shape hunts in classroom and outside
Sort shape cards in different ways
Emphasize: size and orientation don't change the shape

description: Sort and classify shapes based on their attributes

coreConcepts: Attributes: number of sides, corners, faces
Sort by one or more attributes
Same shape can belong to multiple categories
Use describing words: curved, straight, flat, solid
commonMistakes: Thinking shapes can only belong to one group

description: Understand properties of 2D shapes: sides, vertices, angles

coreConcepts: Properties: triangles have 3 sides, quadrilaterals have 4
commonMistakes: Missing vertices or counting them twice
Not recognizing irregular versions of shapes
teachingTips: Build shapes with straws, toothpicks, geoboards

description: Understand properties of 3D shapes: faces, edges, vertices

coreConcepts: Common 3D shapes: cube, sphere, cylinder, cone, pyramid
teachingTips: Count faces, edges, vertices on models

description: Describe position using spatial vocabulary: above, below, beside, in front of, behind

coreConcepts: Relative positions change based on perspective
commonMistakes: Confusing left and right with other positions
Not considering perspective or point of view
Using vague language instead of precise terms
teachingTips: Use toys or blocks to model positions

description: Use positional vocabulary to give and follow directions

coreConcepts: Precise vocabulary: left, right, up, down
Between: position relative to two objects
Combine position words for complex directions
commonMistakes: Not following directions in correct sequence
teachingTips: Grid games: describe how to get from point to point

description: Find area by counting squares or using length × width

coreConcepts: Area measures space inside a shape
Count unit squares to find area
Units are square units (sq cm, sq ft, etc.)
teachingTips: Real contexts: covering a floor, painting a wall
Visual: fill in rectangles on grid paper

description: Find perimeter by adding all side lengths

coreConcepts: Perimeter is distance around a shape
Units are linear units (cm, ft, etc.)
Can find missing side if perimeter is known
commonMistakes: Using square units instead of linear units
teachingTips: Walk around the shape: measure each side
Use string or tape to measure perimeter
Compare: shapes with same area can have different perimeters

description: Solve real-world problems involving area and perimeter

coreConcepts: Identify whether problem asks for area or perimeter
commonMistakes: Finding area when perimeter is needed (or vice versa)
Missing information or assuming square dimensions
teachingTips: Highlight: What does the problem ask for?
Always draw and label a picture
Real projects: design a garden, plan a room
Compare: when do we need area vs perimeter?
Multi-step: find one measure to find the other

description: Identify lines of symmetry in shapes and figures

coreConcepts: Line of symmetry divides shape into two identical halves
Each half is mirror image of the other
Some shapes have multiple lines of symmetry
Some shapes have no lines of symmetry
commonMistakes: Drawing diagonal when not actually symmetrical
Confusing rotational symmetry with line symmetry
Not testing both sides match exactly
teachingTips: Fold paper cutouts to test symmetry
Explore symmetry in letters, shapes, nature
Draw one half, partner completes other half
Count lines of symmetry in regular polygons

description: Work with and analyze symmetric shapes

coreConcepts: Regular polygons have multiple lines of symmetry
commonMistakes: Not recognizing all lines of symmetry
Confusing similar shapes with symmetric shapes
teachingTips: Chart: shape and number of symmetry lines

description: Create symmetric figures by completing the other half

coreConcepts: Reflect points across line of symmetry
Each point and its reflection are same distance from line
commonMistakes: Not measuring distance from line correctly
Making designs that are not actually symmetric
teachingTips: Start with simple shapes on grid paper
Count squares from line of symmetry
Check work by folding or using mirror

description: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction situations

coreConcepts: Understand problem context and what is happening
Identify what is changing (increasing or decreasing)
Write number sentence to match story
commonMistakes: Adding when should subtract (or vice versa)
Choosing operation based on keywords only
teachingTips: Act out problems with objects or students
Draw pictures to show the action
Identify: start amount, change, end amount

description: Solve compare problems to find the difference between quantities

coreConcepts: Compare two quantities to find how many more/less
Can use subtraction or addition to solve
Keywords: more than, fewer than, difference
teachingTips: Line up objects to show comparison
Bar model diagrams: draw and compare bars
Use comparison language: How many more? How many fewer?
Connect to real comparisons: heights, ages, collections

description: Solve problems where the ending amount is unknown

coreConcepts: Addition: joining, putting together → result grows
Subtraction: separating, taking away → result shrinks
teachingTips: Act out with objects: start with some, add/remove more
Most common problem type - build fluency

description: Solve problems where the amount of change is unknown

coreConcepts: Can use subtraction or missing addend
Think: What was added/removed to get from start to end?
teachingTips: Draw diagrams showing before and after
Use missing addend strategy: start + ? = end
Count up from start to end
Real contexts: grew taller, saved money, lost items

description: Estimate sums and differences using rounding and mental math

coreConcepts: Round numbers to make mental math easier
commonMistakes: Rounding all numbers same way regardless of context
Not understanding when estimation is appropriate
teachingTips: When do we need exact vs approximate answers?
Round to nearest 10, 100, etc. for easier computation

description: Use rounding to estimate sums and differences before calculating

coreConcepts: Add or subtract the rounded numbers mentally
Result is an estimate, not exact
Helps check if exact answer is reasonable
commonMistakes: Rounding after calculating instead of before
Using exact calculation when estimate requested
teachingTips: Use compatible numbers (easy to work with)

description: Use estimation to determine if answers are reasonable

teachingTips: Check: Is answer way too big or too small?
Decimal point errors show up clearly

description: Build fluency with number relationships and part-whole understanding

coreConcepts: Numbers can be broken into parts
teachingTips: Use number bond diagrams: circle with two parts
Practice: What goes with 7 to make 10?
Games: number bond flash cards, matching

description: Use make-ten strategy to add numbers efficiently

coreConcepts: Break apart one addend to make 10 first
Ten is a friendly landmark number
commonMistakes: Not seeing when strategy is helpful
teachingTips: Explicit steps: What do I need to make 10?

description: Use doubles facts and near doubles strategy for mental addition

commonMistakes: Adding 2 instead of 1 for near doubles
Confusing which fact to start with
teachingTips: Near doubles: "If I know this double, I know..."
Real contexts: pairs of socks, eyes, hands

description: Understand and apply ratio concepts to compare quantities

coreConcepts: Can write as a:b, a to b, or a/b
teachingTips: Use tape diagrams to visualize ratio relationships
Connect to scaling and proportional thinking
Ratio tables to find equivalent ratios

description: Solve proportions using cross-multiplication and equivalent ratios

coreConcepts: Check solution makes sense in context
teachingTips: Set up with labels: cats/dogs = cats/dogs
Show both cross-multiplication and scaling methods
Real problems: scale drawings, recipes, unit conversion
Verify: plug answer back into original proportion

description: Solve real-world problems involving rates and unit rates

coreConcepts: Unit rate: rate with denominator of 1
Find unit rate to compare and solve
Set up and solve proportions for rates
teachingTips: Better buy problems: price per unit
Connect to slope (rate of change) later

description: Calculate percent of a quantity in real-world situations

commonMistakes: Using percent without converting to decimal
teachingTips: Real contexts: tips, sales tax, discounts
Double number line or bar model
Check: answer should be less than whole (for <100%)

description: Calculate percent increase and decrease

coreConcepts: Amount of change vs percent change
commonMistakes: Using new value as denominator instead of original
Forgetting to multiply by 100 for percent
Not distinguishing amount vs percent change
teachingTips: Always identify original vs new first
Real: population growth, price changes, inflation
Connect to multiplying by growth factor (1.05 for 5% increase)

description: Understand slope as rate of change and steepness

coreConcepts: Positive slope: increases left to right
Negative slope: decreases left to right
Steeper slope = faster rate of change
commonMistakes: Not recognizing zero vs undefined slope
teachingTips: Connect to real rates: speed, cost per item
Staircase analogy: rise = up/down, run = across
Always go from left point to right point
Compare slopes: steeper = larger absolute value

description: Graph linear equations using multiple methods

coreConcepts: Table of values method: choose x, find y
Intercepts method: find x and y intercepts
Slope-intercept: plot b, use m for next points
All solutions lie on the line
Need at least 2 points, use 3 to check
commonMistakes: Not using ruler for straight line
Not extending line through entire grid
teachingTips: Plot at least 3 points to verify
Write equation next to graphed line

description: Use scale factors to enlarge or reduce figures proportionally

coreConcepts: Scale factor = ratio of corresponding lengths
All linear measurements scale by k
commonMistakes: Confusing scale factor with actual measurements
Thinking area scales by k instead of k²
teachingTips: Find k: new length / original length
Apply same k to all dimensions
Connection to dilations in coordinate plane

description: Identify and work with similar figures using proportional relationships
Calculate slope given two coordinate points using the slope formula

coreConcepts: Order matters: subtract in same order
commonMistakes: Mixing up x and y coordinates
Dividing by zero for vertical lines
teachingTips: Emphasize: subtract y's, subtract x's, same order
Plot points and verify with rise/run counting
Practice with all slope types: positive, negative, zero, undefined
Connect to rate of change interpretation

description: Solve real-world problems involving constant rate of change

coreConcepts: Use equation to predict or find values
teachingTips: Highlight: starting amount and how it changes
Table of values helps see pattern
Real contexts: phone plans, rental fees, savings

description: Calculate and interpret average rate of change from tables, graphs, and situations

coreConcepts: Rate of change = change in output / change in input
For linear: rate of change = slope
Can find from table, graph, or equation
teachingTips: Connect to slope and unit rates
From table: pick any two points
Meaning: "for every increase of 1 in x, y changes by..."

description: Substitute values and evaluate expressions using order of operations (GEMS)

coreConcepts: Follow GEMS order: Grouping, Exponents, Multiply/Divide, Add/Subtract
commonMistakes: Not using parentheses for negative values
Order of operations errors (not following GEMS)
Forgetting exponents apply to what's directly before
teachingTips: GEMS reminder: Grouping → Exponents → M/D → A/S

description: Evaluate complex expressions with multiple grouping symbols and operations

commonMistakes: Mixing up which grouping to do first
teachingTips: Circle or highlight innermost grouping first
Work one level at a time
Fraction bar groups numerator and denominator

description: Factor quadratic expressions of the form x² + bx + c and ax² + bx + c

coreConcepts: Factor x² + bx + c into (x + p)(x + q) where p·q = c and p + q = b
For ax² + bx + c: find factors of ac that add to b
Some quadratics are prime (cannot be factored)
commonMistakes: Forgetting to factor out GCF first
Assuming all quadratics can be factored
teachingTips: List factor pairs of c, find pair that adds to b
Use algebra tiles or area model for visual

description: Factor expressions in the form a² - b² into (a+b)(a-b)

coreConcepts: Both terms must be perfect squares
Can combine with other factoring techniques
Sum of squares a² + b² does NOT factor (over reals)
commonMistakes: Trying to factor sum of squares
Forgetting to check for GCF first

description: Plot ordered pairs accurately on the coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Move horizontally x units, then vertically y units
Right/up are positive, left/down are negative
commonMistakes: Going up/down first instead of left/right
teachingTips: Mnemonic: "along the hall, up the stairs"
Connect to real: maps, battleship game

description: Identify and work with the four quadrants of the coordinate plane

teachingTips: Counter-clockwise from upper right: I, II, III, IV
Sign chart: I(+,+), II(-,+), III(-,-), IV(+,-)
Practice: which quadrant contains each point?

description: Find distance between two points using the distance formula

teachingTips: Check: distance matches diagonal on graph

description: Find the midpoint between two coordinate points

coreConcepts: Average the x-coordinates, average the y-coordinates
Midpoint is exactly halfway between points
Can verify: distance from each endpoint equal
commonMistakes: Adding instead of averaging (forgetting division by 2)
Writing as two numbers instead of ordered pair
teachingTips: Remember: AVERAGE of x's and y's
Plot points and verify midpoint visually
Check: midpoint is between the two points
Real: center of a segment, halfway point on map

description: Solve and graph one-step inequalities

coreConcepts: Flip inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative
commonMistakes: Not flipping inequality sign when using negatives
Wrong direction on number line graph
teachingTips: Emphasize: flip ONLY for multiply/divide by negative
Test multiple values from solution set
Number line: open circle for < or >, closed for ≤ or ≥

description: Solve inequalities requiring two operations

coreConcepts: Same as equations: box the variable term, think outside the box
Outside the box: use opposites; Inside the box: divide it out
Flip inequality if multiply/divide by negative
commonMistakes: Forgetting to flip when dividing by negative
teachingTips: Always graph solution on number line

description: Solve complex inequalities with variables on both sides

coreConcepts: Remember: flip for multiply/divide by negative
Infinite solutions or no solution possible
teachingTips: Combine like terms before moving variables
Move smaller variable term to other side

description: Graph solution sets of inequalities using number lines

coreConcepts: Left for less than, right for greater than
commonMistakes: Wrong type of circle (open vs closed)
teachingTips: Mnemonic: open circle looks like "oh no, not included"
Test a value to verify shading direction
Practice reading graphs back to inequalities
Use different colors for compound inequalities
Real: acceptable ranges, speed limits, age restrictions

description: Understand and use inequality symbols and interval notation

coreConcepts: < means less than, > means greater than
≤ means less than or equal to, ≥ means greater than or equal to
Point of symbol points to smaller value
Can write solutions multiple ways: x > 3 or (3, ∞)
teachingTips: Symbol points to smaller number like arrow
Real: age requirements, weight limits, temperature ranges

description: Choose and compare appropriate measures of center (mean, median, mode)

coreConcepts: Mean: affected by outliers, best for symmetric data
Median: resistant to outliers, best for skewed data
Mode: for categorical or most frequent
Choose based on data distribution and question
commonMistakes: Always using mean without considering outliers
Not recognizing when data is skewed
teachingTips: Show same data set with outlier: mean shifts, median stable
Real: home prices (median better), test scores (mean ok)
Visual: dot plots or histograms show distribution shape
Discuss: when is each measure most useful?
Practice identifying skewed vs symmetric data

description: Find and interpret the interquartile range as a measure of spread

coreConcepts: Q1: median of lower half, Q3: median of upper half
Measures spread of middle 50% of data
Larger IQR = more spread out data
teachingTips: Order data, find median, split in half at median
Find median of each half (Q1 and Q3)
Real: understanding variability in test scores, prices

description: Understand standard deviation as a measure of spread

coreConcepts: Measures typical distance from the mean
Larger SD = more spread out data
Units are same as original data
Most data falls within 1-2 SD of mean
commonMistakes: Thinking all SD calculations are same
teachingTips: Use technology to calculate (formula is complex)
Compare: small SD = data clustered, large SD = data scattered
Visual: dot plots with different SDs
Real: quality control, test score consistency

description: Create and interpret histograms to display numerical data

coreConcepts: Bars represent ranges (bins), not individual values
commonMistakes: Gaps between bars like bar graph

description: Create and interpret box plots using five-number summary

coreConcepts: Five-number summary: min, Q1, median, Q3, max
Whiskers extend to min and max
teachingTips: Draw scale, plot five numbers, construct box
Box shows IQR, line in box is median
Real: comparing test scores, salaries, temperatures

description: Select and create appropriate data displays for different data types

coreConcepts: Categorical data: bar graphs, circle graphs
Numerical data: histograms, box plots, dot plots
Choose based on data type and question
commonMistakes: Wrong display for the question asked
teachingTips: Decision tree: categorical or numerical? one set or comparing?
Practice: match data to best display type
Create multiple displays for same data

description: Identify and extend patterns in arithmetic sequences

coreConcepts: Common difference: constant change between terms
commonMistakes: Confusing term number with term value
teachingTips: Use tables: term number and term value
Real: saving /week, ticket numbers, seating rows

description: Identify and extend geometric (exponential) sequences

coreConcepts: Common ratio: multiply by constant each time
Find pattern by dividing consecutive terms
teachingTips: Find ratio: divide term by previous term
Visual: dramatic growth curves vs linear
Real: bacteria doubling, compound interest, viral spread

description: Find sums of arithmetic sequences

coreConcepts: Arithmetic series has pattern in partial sums
Can add terms directly for short sequences
Pair terms from ends: first+last, second+second-to-last
teachingTips: Real: total savings over time, stacking blocks

description: Find sums of geometric sequences (finite)

coreConcepts: Can calculate directly for short sequences
teachingTips: Foundation for geometric series formula later

description: Understand and analyze quadratic functions and their key features

coreConcepts: Standard form: f(x) = ax² + bx + c
Parabola shape: opens up if a > 0, down if a < 0
Axis of symmetry: vertical line through vertex
commonMistakes: Confusing vertex form with standard form
teachingTips: Start with simple: y = x², y = -x², y = 2x²
Vertex form y = a(x-h)² + k shows vertex (h,k)
Real: projectile motion, profit models, area problems

description: Graph parabolas and identify key features from equations

coreConcepts: Find vertex: x = -b/2a, then substitute for y
Find x-intercepts: factor or quadratic formula
Plot vertex and intercepts, sketch parabola
Use symmetry to plot additional points
teachingTips: Mirror points across axis of symmetry

description: Model and analyze exponential growth situations

coreConcepts: Growth form: y = a(1 + r)ᵗ where r > 0
teachingTips: Real: population, bacteria, compound interest, viral spread
Compare to linear: exponential eventually faster

description: Model and analyze exponential decay situations

coreConcepts: Decay form: y = a(1 - r)ᵗ where 0 < r < 1
Approaches zero but never reaches it
Half-life: time for half to remain
teachingTips: Real: radioactive decay, depreciation, drug elimination, cooling
Compare to growth: same structure, different base

description: Calculate and interpret average rate of change for any function

coreConcepts: Same as slope between two points
For nonlinear: varies over different intervals
teachingTips: For nonlinear: changes based on interval
Real: average velocity, average cost per unit

description: Identify and analyze parent functions and their characteristics

coreConcepts: Parent functions: simplest form of each family
teachingTips: Create function family chart with graphs
Key features: domain, range, intercepts, symmetry, end behavior
Each parent is building block for family
Memorize graphs of all parent functions

description: Understand and classify functions into families

coreConcepts: Polynomial family: linear, quadratic, cubic, quartic
Radical family: square root, cube root
Recognize family from equation or graph
teachingTips: Compare: what do all quadratics have in common?
Visual: overlay transformed functions on parent
Key question: what is the parent function?

description: Apply and identify transformations of functions (shifts, stretches, reflections)

coreConcepts: Four main transformations: shifts, stretches, compressions, reflections
Vertical shift: f(x) + k (up if k > 0)
Horizontal shift: f(x - h) (right if h > 0)
Reflections: -f(x) over x-axis, f(-x) over y-axis
teachingTips: Start with parent, apply one transformation at a time
Horizontal: opposite of what you think (x - 3 goes right!)
Reverse: write equation from transformed graph

description: Apply and identify vertical shifts of functions

coreConcepts: f(x) + k shifts graph up k units (k > 0)
f(x) + k shifts graph down |k| units (k < 0)
teachingTips: Simple: just move graph up or down
Check: what happens to (0, 0) on parent?
Every point moves same vertical distance

description: Apply and identify horizontal shifts of functions

coreConcepts: f(x - h) shifts graph RIGHT h units (h > 0)
f(x + h) shifts graph LEFT h units
commonMistakes: Direction: x - 3 goes RIGHT (most common error!)
teachingTips: Memory: opposite of sign! x - h → right
Test: plug in x-values to see shift
Ask: what x makes (x - 3) = 0? x = 3 (shift right 3)
Every point moves same horizontal distance

description: Solve systems of linear inequalities algebraically and graphically

coreConcepts: Solution is region satisfying all inequalities
Graph each inequality on same plane
Test points to verify solution region
teachingTips: Graph one inequality at a time
Test point in overlap to verify

description: Graph solution regions for systems of inequalities on coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Graph boundary line for each inequality
Dashed for < or >, solid for ≤ or ≥
Vertices are intersection points of boundaries
teachingTips: Test (0,0) if not on boundary to determine shading

description: Use linear programming to optimize under constraints

coreConcepts: Feasible region contains all possible solutions
Optimal solution at vertex of feasible region
Test all vertices to find maximum/minimum
teachingTips: Step 1: Define variables and write inequalities
Step 4: Evaluate objective function at each vertex

description: Solve and graph absolute value inequalities

coreConcepts: |x| > a means x < -a or x > a (outside)
teachingTips: Graph: < gives interval, > gives two rays

description: Perform and analyze dilations (size transformations) on the coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Scale factor k from center point
Multiply coordinates by k: (x,y) → (kx, ky) from origin
commonMistakes: Confusing scale factor with actual size
teachingTips: Distance from center changes by factor k
Real: photo enlargement, maps, scale models
Connect to scale factor and similar figures

description: Write formal proofs using postulates, theorems, and logical reasoning

coreConcepts: Each step justified by definition, postulate, or theorem
Logical flow from given to prove
commonMistakes: Assuming what you're trying to prove
teachingTips: Start with given, work toward goal

description: Use multiplication to count outcomes in multi-stage events

coreConcepts: Multiply number of choices at each stage
If event A has m outcomes and event B has n outcomes, total = m × n
teachingTips: Real: passwords, license plates, menu choices
Build from 2 stages to many stages
Check with listing for simple cases

description: Apply various counting techniques to complex situations
Calculate permutations when order matters

coreConcepts: nPr = n!/(n-r)! for r objects from n
teachingTips: Start with simple: how many ways to arrange ABC?
Real: race positions, lock combinations (actually permutations!), passwords

description: Calculate combinations when order does not matter

coreConcepts: Combination: selection where order doesn't matter
nCr = n!/(r!(n-r)!) for r objects from n
{AB, BA} is same combination but different permutations
Use when order is not important
teachingTips: Key: ABC and BAC are same combination
Calculator has nCr or C(n,r) function
Real: committees, teams, lottery, pizza toppings
nCr always ≤ nPr for same n, r

description: Calculate probability of compound events using AND and OR

coreConcepts: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B) if independent
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)
teachingTips: Real: multiple coin flips, drawing cards

description: Calculate and interpret conditional probability

coreConcepts: P(A|B): probability of A given B has occurred
Formula: P(A|B) = P(A and B) / P(B)
commonMistakes: Not restricting to correct sample space
teachingTips: Read: probability of A given B
Independence: events don't affect each other

description: Read and write sums using sigma (Σ) notation

coreConcepts: Σ(i=1 to n) aᵢ = a₁ + a₂ + ... + aₙ
Index variable (often i, k, or n)
teachingTips: Expand first few terms to understand
Index is placeholder, can use any letter
Compact way to write long sums

description: Evaluate and manipulate expressions in summation notation

coreConcepts: Σ(aᵢ + bᵢ) = Σaᵢ + Σbᵢ (sum of sums)

description: Find sums of finite arithmetic and geometric series

coreConcepts: Geometric series: Sₙ = a₁(1 - rⁿ)/(1 - r)
teachingTips: Find needed values: a₁, n, d or r

description: Apply and derive formulas for arithmetic and geometric series

coreConcepts: Arithmetic: Sₙ = n/2(2a₁ + (n-1)d) or n(a₁ + aₙ)/2
teachingTips: Derive geometric: multiply by r, subtract

description: Approximate area under curves using Riemann sums

coreConcepts: Left endpoint, right endpoint, midpoint methods
commonMistakes: Not understanding which endpoint to use

description: Use various methods to approximate area under curves

coreConcepts: Trapezoidal rule: average of left and right
Increasing number of subdivisions improves accuracy
Exact area is limit as n → ∞
teachingTips: Compare different methods on same function
Real: distance from velocity, total growth
